nodes.bodyText:
When does it happen exactly? I would like to understand when this case happens and when the other case happens?

As far I was able to observe/test, this case happens when the workflow run was triggered by a pull request and not just merely by a push to a branch that does not yet have a PR.

Typically, I don't understand why we only disable backport PRs in the other case.

The idea here is that there is no guessing when you have a PR because the PR clearly defines the target branch. So for some foo-backport-bar branch (or whatever) that already has a PR, GIB can simply take the target branch from the PR as reference and compare to that (e.g. 1.10).

I don't understand exactly how things work for a PR because the remote master might be totally different from the one used to create the PR

When gathering the changes, the source branch (=from where the "working branch", or in GIB terms "base branch", was branched off) is not so important. GIB or better to say JGit will find the common merge base and do the comparison from there.
Btw, I am still hoping that someone with write access to this repo will try my "Idea for testing this closer to reality" (see PR description).
In my fork I wasn't able to properly test with multiple repos. But come to think of it, maybe I should just fork again from my fork to try to simulate it.

nodes.bodyText:
PULL_REQUEST_BASE is not a branch but a sha

Yes.

a sha that points to the commit on top of which we have added the commits in the PR? Right?

Only if e.g. master did not receive any new commits since the PR branch was created.
There is a good explanation here: https://github.community/t/how-to-get-base-sha-when-using-pull-request-target/142021/6

If so, in this case, I don't want to use GIB for backport PRs either.

Personally I think with a PR it is pretty safe already since you have a clear merge target/comparison reference (the most recent SHA at PR creation time from e.g. 1.10). Additionally, with this PR, master and release branches are still built fully.
But these are just my 2 cents and if you want to play it extra safe so be it.

If this case doesn't concern PRs, I would just disable the incremental build altogether.

This would mean that branches in forks are always built fully. That's a pretty "hard" decision, IMO.
That's also why I asked on Zulip whether we can always expected "backport" to be contained in names of branches that do not target master but a release branch instead (e.g. 1.10).
Btw, it is not a problem if master has advanced since creating the branch because the history of master is never rewritten (I suppose).
